author: barnabemonnot
content: I recently went through the codebase of ethgasstation to understand how the estimation is done. I can say that it is rather complex (props to whoever maintains it!) but the gist is that they both look at historical prices and also monitor whether transactions sent at the price they recommend eventually go through (if they don't, the oracle is adjusted). All this is done to avoid the reflexivity inherent in any pay-your-bid system: users want to know what others are paying so that they don't overpay, and so as Micah said, the problem is chaotic. I don't know that they can be improved much because this is inherent to the setting. 1559 for instance breaks this by making basefee objective (since it cannot costlessly be manipulated)

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.  Node eviction strategies aren't finalized yet, and since they mostly aren't part of consensus different clients may have different eviction strategies.  However, most clients will probably support "local" transactions which will just keep getting resubmitted as the base_fee fluctuates.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> Metamask could add a gas price range and continuously increase the gas price for the tx after each block
this was essentially the escalator proposal. it guarantees inclusion at some point (as long as you allow for the increases to be large enough) but not necessarily next-block inclusion. it also depends on how granular your measurements of the transaction pool are, since shifts can come very rapidly.

author: sky.cactus
content: My suspicion is that often people are setting low gas prices because they don't want to overpay, not because they are trying to get a significant bargain under current gas price.  This is a fundamental problem of first price auctions which humans are generally bad at doing intuitively.
